Here is a more basic question:
Why is authentication part of the HTTP
specification at all?

You can always generate single-use or secret URLs
for applications that need them.

And if the issue is sharing information, that
would come under the scope of people mailing each
other the information as well...

What are the actual use-cases for HTTP-auth?

On 26 Feb 2003, Nic Ferrier wrote:

> "S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...> writes:
>
> > Hey - I just found out there was a note back in 1999 about using HTML forms
> > to do authentication.
> > I haven't read it fully, but this is one of my pet peeves with HTTP and the
> > 'visual Web' - no visibility of security information in messages. (leading
> > to sessions, cookies, wacky urls, etc.)
> >
> > ===
> > http://www.w3.org/TR/1999/NOTE-authentform-19990203
> >
> > [...]
> > This proposal suggests extensions to HTML forms to overcome their present
> > security problems by integrating them with HTTP (or other security sublayer)
> > mechanisms. It calls for a new type of form; the AUTHFORM and new values for
> > the TYPE attribute of the INPUT element and SELECT block.
> > [...]
>
> I've been thinking about this as well. I'm due to give an
> evangelizing talk about REST for a client and I know that this is
> going to come up.
>
> My experience of HTTP authentication is that the fixed user interface
> makes it unpopular with users (or at least website designers) and that
> has a knock on effect on the architecture of web services components
> built as part of the same application.
>
>
> It seems the ideas put forward in the link above were not
> popular. Adding stuff to HTML doesn't seem like the right thing to do
> anyway.
>
> I've always wondered why an authentication response couldn't have an
> entity associated with it, either in the response body or referenced
> via some content-location like header.
>
> If it were possible to associate an entity with the authentication
> then browsers could render it when they find it and use the standard
> dialog box when they don't.
>
> Would that sort of scheme violate REST principles in anyway?
>
>
> Nic
